title: Raptors hijab a slam dunk, teen says
text:
First NBA team to sell a branded hijab

“It’s about time.”

That’s how 17-year-old basketball player Rumaysa Khan reacted to news that the Toronto Raptors are the first NBA team to sell a hijab with their logo on it.

“We’re out here,” said the Grade 12 student from Mississauga, Ont., who has been playing basketball since Grade 3.

“All these Muslim girls are out here playing sports” and it’s about time professional leagues started paying attention, she said.

You don’t have to be a Raptors fan to appreciate the meaning behind the merchandise, Rumaysa said.

“This is another step in inclusivity,” she said.

The company that makes the Raptors’ merchandise, Maple Leaf Sports and Entertainment, unveiled the new Nike Pro hijabs with the logo on the side — three claw marks on a basketball — on Sept. 13.

Reactions online were mixed.

Some people commented that it was strange to put a corporate logo on a piece of clothing with religious significance.

Others said they see the hijab — which is a type of headscarf worn by some Muslim women — as a symbol of oppression.

That doesn’t sit right with Rumaysa, who said nobody forced her to wear a hijab.

She said her dad was shocked when she walked downstairs wearing her headscarf one morning back in Grade 8 — and she’s been wearing one ever since.

The decision is between "only you and God,” she said.

Other female athletes were quick to defend the new product on social media.

“Much respect to the Raptors for this level of inclusion,” said U.S. college basketball star Bilqis Abdul-Qaadir.

The 28-year-old made headlines in 2014 when she was prevented from playing overseas because of the International Basketball Federation’s (FIBA) headgear rule, which banned hijabs.

That rule changed in 2017.

“I think I have a new favourite team,” Abdul-Qaadir said on Instagram.

Asiyah Hoda, 10, already owns a Raptors shirt, jersey and flag. Now she’s saving up for her very own Raptors hijab.

The Grade 5 student from Mississauga is a serious Raptors fan.

She said she was excited to see the team’s commercial for their new merch, even though the $40 price tag is “a bit expensive.”

“It was cool to see people that looked like me” in the ad, she said.

Asiyah Hoda, 10, left, said she and her family watched every single Raptors game during the 2019 NBA Finals, and she’s saving up to buy her own Raptors hijab. (Submitted by Asiyah Hoda)

Asiyah, who plays for a girls-only development league called the Mississauga Monarchs, said she’s practised wearing her hijab on the court a few times.

This year, she plans to wear it every time she plays.

“It could be inspiring to other younger girls,” Asiyah said.
description: Young Muslim basketball players react to the Raptors’ decision to become the first NBA team to sell a team-branded hijab.
